Award.AwardTitle: Absolute Time - And Space - Resolved Measurements Of High Field Ionization In Plasmas
Award.AbstractNarration:
Ionization of atoms and molecules is a ubiquitous process common to all instances of the interaction of intense laser pulses with matter. It is central to industrial and defense applications, including strong laser heating of droplets to produce radiation for next generation semiconductor lithography, studies of high energy density matter on the National Ignition Facility, and propagation of high power laser pulses through the atmosphere.

Despite the importance of laser-driven ionization, the process has never before been measured with ultrafast time and micron space resolution in combination with absolute yield. This information is essential for both applications and for verification of underlying theoretical models. In this work, these measurements will be accomplished for the first time with a special laser-based strobe-like diagnostic capable of achieving these time and space resolutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
When a high intensity laser pulse propagates through a medium, such as the atmosphere, it can radically change the medium as it propagates, and the transiently changing medium can act back on the laser pulse, affecting its propagation. In air, for example, one type of medium change is ionization, in which a sufficiently strong laser field rips electrons off the atoms and molecules, forming a plasma. The other effect is that the strongly perturbed atoms and molecules respond in such a way to turn the medium into a self-lens that focuses the pulse. The now-freed electrons and the residual neutral atoms, both exposed to the strong laser field, can dramatically effect propagation, leading to self-guiding of the pulse. One of the goals of this project was to learn precisely how that happens, and for that to be accomplished, the experiments needed to precisely measure—on a 10^-15 second timescale-- the ultrafast ionization rate (the rate at which electrons are ripped off) and the laser-induced distortions of the electronic orbitals in the residual neutral atoms and molecules. These goals were achieved, with a particularly remarkable result being that the distortions of the neutrals at very high laser fields had the same character—being proportional to the laser intensity-- as at very low fields.


The second part of the project was to understand and apply the intense laser propagation itself. Here we discovered that both the plasma formation and the spinning of air’s molecules by the laser field can heat the air enough to form a long-lived waveguide into which a secondary very high average power laser pulse could be injected. This process opens the way for short pulse written waveguides in the atmosphere for applications in remote sensing, communications, and defense. The project demonstrated that all such pulses that propagate in this way—self-focusing, ionization, and self-guiding--naturally give rise to a “spatio-temporal optical vortex”, or STOV, which is indestructible and serves to make the self-guiding process robust. STOVs could lead to applications in communications and high intensity laser propagation.

 


Last Modified: 06/08/2018
Modified by: Howard M Milchberg
